image.altText: A commonwealth bank sign and logo.

items.synopsis: Customers of Australia's largest bank have been unable to access their money or use online banking due to a widespread technical outage.

title.children: 'I cannot use my own money': CommBank customers 'livid' as tech issue crashes banking services

image.altText: A graphic comprised of images of four men in suits. Behind them is an audio wave form.

items.synopsis: As the walls close in on the conspirators behind the massive Plutus tax scam, they have no idea police are listening in on every conversation.

title.children: 'Oh, we're cooked': Australia's biggest tax scam is unravelling. Police are listening to every word

image.altText: A three-letter logo "pwc" on a wall, with a head in shadow walking past beneath it.

items.synopsis: Nine senior partners have been stood down since the consultancy firm's tax leak scandal came to light.

title.children: Acting PwC chief executive flags 'severe' consequences during NSW parliamentary inquiry

image.altText: Pwc Logo

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is down in early trade, along with electronic banking for many CBA customers. PwC is accused of "self-centred" motives behind its planned business split. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: PwC accused of 'phoenix' split, customers await answers on CBA outage, ASX slips on miners

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a turbulent weekend in Russia, but quite serene on Asian share markets today. The ASX 200 lost 0.3% to close at 7,079 points, with the All Ords mirroring that performance to close at 7,264. Japan's Nikkei was off 0.3% at 32,699 points approaching the end of trade. Hong Kong's Hang Seng was a little weaker, while mainland China's two major indices in Shanghai and Shenzen saw bigger falls above 1.5%. Swissquote Bank senior analyst Ipek Ozkardeskaya said markets are likely to remain largely unaffected by developments in Russia until they signal a major shift in the war outlook. "The Wagner incident will likely remain broadly ignored by investors, unless there are fresh developments that could change the course of the war in Ukraine," she wrote. "Until then, markets will be back to business as usual." Locally, the biggest gainers were gold miners, led by a 4.9% jump for Capricorn Metals, amid some search for safe havens. Graincorp was also up 2.4%, with Ukraine critical to the global supply, and therefore price, of many grains. Grocery wholesaler and hardware store operator Metcash gained 4.7% on its annual profit result. Some of the biggest losers were Syrah Resources (-6%), Imugene (-4.5%), Star Entertainment (-3.8%) and Mineral Resources (-3.5%) .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wagner revolt has little effect on markets

children.content: It was a turbulent weekend in Russia, but quite serene on Asian share markets today.
The
ASX 200 lost 0.3% to close at 7,079 points
, with the
All Ords
mirroring that performance to close at 7,264.
Japan's Nikkei was off 0.3% at 32,699 points
approaching the end of trade.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng
was a little weaker, while mainland China's two major indices in
Shanghai and Shenzen saw bigger falls above 1.5%
Swissquote Bank senior analyst
Ipek Ozkardeskaya
said markets are likely to remain largely unaffected by developments in Russia until they signal a major shift in the war outlook.
"The Wagner incident will likely remain broadly ignored by investors, unless there are fresh developments that could change the course of the war in Ukraine," she wrote.
"Until then, markets will be back to business as usual."
Locally, the biggest gainers were gold miners, led by a
4.9% jump for Capricorn Metals
, amid some search for safe havens.
Graincorp was also up 2.4%
, with Ukraine critical to the global supply, and therefore price, of many grains.
Grocery wholesaler and hardware store operator
Metcash gained 4.7%
on its annual profit result.
Some of the biggest losers were
Syrah Resources (-6%), Imugene (-4.5%), Star Entertainment (-3.8%) and Mineral Resources (-3.5%)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The acting chief executive of PwC Australia Kristin Stubbins — who will soon be replaced by a new CEO Kevin Burrows who is coming in from Singapore to take charge — appeared before a NSW parliamentary inquiry today. Ms Stubbins is certainly getting a lot of practice at apologising for PwC's past behaviour, but many of the politicians are not buying it. Many are also sceptical of the recently revealed deal to sell the PwC government consulting business to private equity firm Allegro for $1. The ABC's Isobel Roe and Nassim Khadem have today's hearing covered in this article.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC grilled by NSW parliamentarians

featuredLink.title: Acting PwC chief executive flags 'severe' consequences during NSW parliamentary inquiry

children.content: The
acting chief executive of PwC Australia Kristin Stubbins
— who will soon be replaced by a
new CEO Kevin Burrows
who is coming in from Singapore to take charge — appeared before a
NSW parliamentary inquiry
today.
Ms Stubbins is certainly getting a lot of practice at apologising for PwC's past behaviour, but many of the politicians are not buying it.
Many are also sceptical of the recently revealed deal to sell the PwC government consulting business to private equity firm
Allegro
for $1.
The ABC's
Isobel Roe and Nassim Khadem
have today's hearing covered in this article.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Finally an update from the Commonwealth Bank about its tech issues that have plagued many customers for much of the day. The bank says its services are recovering following "intermittent issues" today. It has thanked customers for their patience as it continues to bring services back online. The ABC understands the problems were caused by internal technology issues and are not the result of any external cyber attack or interference. It is also understood that the issues did not affect all CBA customers and the bank is still trying to ascertain how many customers were affected. Staff at the bank warn that it could still take some time for all systems to operate as normal for everyone and that affected customers should be on the lookout for the possibility of failed or duplicate payments. Commonwealth Bank group chief information officer Gavin Munro apologised to those affected. "We sincerely apologise to customers who experienced disruption to their banking services today," he said in a statement. "We know how much customers depend on us and are very sorry for the intermittent service issues experienced by many people today."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA says normal service being restored

children.content: Finally
an update from the Commonwealth Bank
about its tech issues that have plagued many customers for much of the day.
The bank says its services are recovering following "intermittent issues" today. It has thanked customers for their patience as it continues to bring services back online.
The ABC understands the
problems were caused by internal technology issues
and are not the result of any external cyber attack or interference.
It is also understood that
the issues did not affect all CBA customers
and the bank is still trying to ascertain how many customers were affected.

Staff at the bank warn that it could still take some time for all systems to operate as normal for everyone and that affected customers should be on the lookout for the possibility of failed or duplicate payments.
Commonwealth Bank group chief information officer Gavin Munro
apologised to those affected.
"We sincerely apologise to customers who experienced disruption to their banking services today," he said in a statement.
"We know how much customers depend on us and are very sorry for the intermittent service issues experienced by many people today."

image.altText: A composite image of two men. One in a suit, the other in a military flack jacket

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced another military support package for Ukraine worth $110 million.

title.children: Australia commits another $110m to Ukraine's war effort

image.altText: Alexander Lukashenko and Vladimir Putin walking together

items.synopsis: Just a month after he was fighting off poisoning rumours, Alexander Lukashenko stunned almost everyone by saving Vladimir Putin from the brink.

title.children: In his greatest crisis, one man came to Putin's rescue. Here's why everyone is confused

image.altText: A man with his face blurred is flanked by several police officers as he's led to a police van

items.synopsis: Six men are charged with affray after an alleged fight broke out between members and associates of the underworld crew in the city last week.

title.children: 'Immense pressure': Police land blow to Alameddine crew after Sydney CBD brawl

image.altText: The community gathering space of the new Altona Pier redevelopment is pictured looking back towards the pier's entrance.

items.synopsis: By the end of this year, Altona's 135-year-old timber pier will be pulled down and replaced by a modern version. Despite mourning the loss of the old, locals say the new design does well to incorporate elements of the historic structure.

title.children: By this summer, a historic pier in Melbourne's west will be gone. But locals are happy with the revamp

image.altText: Simon Crean

items.synopsis: As Labor leader in 2003 Simon Crean called Australia's decision to send troops to Iraq wrong, reckless and unnecessary as he stood up to US president George W Bush.

title.children: Simon Crean never got to lead Labor to an election but he did stand up to a US president

image.altText: A security fence lines an empty block of land.

items.synopsis: The High Court dismisses a bid by Russia to prevent the Commonwealth from taking control of a site it leased for a new embassy.

title.children: High Court throws out Russia's bid to stop Australian government taking control of embassy site

image.altText: APN: Putin Forum

items.synopsis: The prime minister says the aborted mutiny that rattled Russia at the weekend shows the invasion of Ukraine has been a "disaster" for Vladimir Putin.

title.children: Albanese dubs aborted Russian mutiny a 'disaster' for Putin

image.altText: A cyclist sign on Black Forest Drive near Woodend in the Macedon Ranges, in central Victoria.

items.synopsis: A Victorian cycling club that lost one of its own in a crash last year is concerned it is not being heard, as authorities work to finalise designs for safety improvements on the deadly stretch of road.

title.children: Cyclists 'no better off' despite years of advocacy about deadly road

image.altText: A sinkhole on a wet path

items.synopsis: After heavy rain, a 2-metre deep sinkhole has appeared in Mount Gambier's CBD. The council is now mapping other areas vulnerable to subsidence to "stay on the front foot".

title.children: 'Huge' sinkhole appears in SA city as rock 'dissolves like sugar'

image.altText: A young man on the left wearing a red hoodie, next to him an older man with grey-ish hair, wearing glasses. Both are smiling.

items.synopsis: Christine Dawood says her son Suleman never went anywhere without a Rubik's Cube, and was excited about solving the puzzle "3,700 metres below sea at the Titanic".

title.children: Teen who died in Titanic submersible implosion wanted to break Rubik's Cube world record, mother tells BBC

image.altText: Megan Davis standing in front of a bright orange rock, Uluru, with a straight face.

items.synopsis: Megan Davis found an old copy of the Australian Constitution at the back of a book when she was a girl. Thirty years later, she wants to change it to give the Voice to her people.

title.children: She was 12 when she fell in love with the Constitution. Now Megan Davis is giving everything she's got to change it

image.altText: A young boy is smiling in a red t-shirt.

items.synopsis: The confidence NSW Police displayed in a breakthrough in the missing person's case dissipated after the boy's foster parents became the focus of homicide investigations.

title.children: On what would have been William Tyrrell's 12th birthday, police remain tight-lipped on one theory

image.altText: An empty apartment with windows looking out over the city to the horizon.

items.synopsis: Around the world, the idea of turning offices underused in the wake of COVID's work-from-home phenomenon into housing is a hot topic. But experts say such projects are few and far between in Australia for a reason, and creating affordable housing from office buildings is harder than it seems.

title.children: The pros and cons of turning office buildings into housing

image.altText: Two gymnasts wearing Team Australia tops smile at the camera wearing their medals from the Special Olympics.

items.synopsis: With personal bests and medals aplenty, the Australian team finishes on a high at the Special Olympics World Games in Germany.

title.children: Team Australia wins 13 gold medals at Special Olympics World Games

image.altText: Thunderbirds players hug

items.synopsis: A last-minute pitch by South Australia's premier to bring the Super Netball grand final to Adelaide after the Thunderbirds' extraordinary win has fallen flat, with Peter Malinauskas saying the commercial deal was "almost impossible" to unpick.

title.children: SA rebuffed in last-minute bid to bring Super Netball grand final to Thunderbirds' home ground

image.altText: adult whale swimming with newborn calf in ocean

items.synopsis: Reports of a possible deceased whale floating near a Coffs Harbour beach have turned out to be a slow-moving mother whale with her newborn calf. The new calf was spotted on ORCCA whale census day, "adding one more additional whale to the tally".

title.children: 'One more to the tally': Whale mother and baby filmed moments after birth on whale census day

image.altText: Shane Barker

items.synopsis: Shane Barker was found dead in his Campbell Town home in 2009 after being shot four times. Fourteen years on, a jury is deciding if a husband and wife were behind the killing.

title.children: A husband and wife stand accused of murdering their son-in-law 14 years ago. Here's the evidence a jury has heard during the trial

image.altText: Shadowy image of Daryl Maguire, bald and on a profile

items.synopsis: The former Wagga Wagga MP will face court over evidence he gave to ICAC in 2018, where he denied seeking payment for brokering a property deal.

title.children: Gladys Berejiklian's former partner Daryl Maguire faces fresh charge of misleading evidence

image.altText: Spillage from a dam at Basket Range leaving debris, rocks and mud everywhere

items.synopsis: A watch-and-act message is in place for a dam at high risk of failure south of Adelaide and a separate warning is in place for a dam in the Adelaide Hills, but crews are confident they will be able to mitigate risks.

title.children: Emergency crews continue to monitor Adelaide dams at risk of failing

image.altText: unidentified tradesperson at flood affected home in skipton

items.synopsis: One tradie can be seen urinating behind a fence at the 170-year-old home and leaving a dead animal on the doorstep before laughing.

title.children: Tradies' bad behaviour at flood-damaged home caught on CCTV

image.altText: Clancy Overell and Errol Parker sitting at a desk with newspapers in front of them, one holding a coffee mug, both in Akubras

items.synopsis: It may be a satirical publication, but the impact of The Betoota Advocate is being felt in the tiny outback town that bears its name.

title.children: What happens when you're the mayor of a ghost town and it becomes an international sensation?

image.altText: Elton John Glastonbury 2023

items.synopsis: More than 200,000 people poured into the UK's Glastonbury Festival over the weekend.

title.children: From Elton John's last UK gig to Cate Blanchett's surprise performance, here's what you missed at Glastonbury 2023

image.altText: A wide image showing a large crowd in the stands and grounds of an open-roof stadium, many holding one hand in the air

items.synopsis: State media says about 120,000 people took part in the rallies across Pyongyang to mark the 73rd anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War.

title.children: North Korea vows 'war of revenge' at mass anti-US rallies in Pyongyang

image.altText: a woman at a restaurant food pass, looking at a food order

items.synopsis: West End used to be populated by thespians and proletariats, but locals say gentrification has priced them out.

title.children: 'Worst-case scenario, we close': The cost of gentrification for West End's small traders

image.altText: A ute causes a splash as it drives through water on a highway, with a dark sedan pulled over on the side of the road

items.synopsis: Authorities have warned travellers to leave the Gibb River Road today ahead of a likely closure tomorrow, while low-level crossings over the Fitzroy River are also expected to close.

title.children: Travellers urged to reconsider plans as unseasonable rain puts Kimberley on alert

image.altText: An aerial photo grave of the outback cemetery

items.synopsis: In outback Queensland, a chance meeting of two women has helped uncover the lost stories of those buried in a ghost town's cemetery, from a baby buried on Christmas Day, to a teen blacksmith who died tragically during a journey to see the doctor.

title.children: Amateur historians help shed light on forgotten past of abandoned cemetery
